item.title: iPad
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

Jailbreaking modifies the bootloader allowing you to run unsigned code. Which then modifies the OS. I mean it has something to do with the OS, but it’s not dependant on the OS in terms of the act of jailbreaking. Just because the exploit out for the iPhone/iPod touch uses the current OS, doesn’t mean it will work for the iPad, it uses different hardware. And the exploit will more than likely have been fixed.

Read full topic

item.title: iPad
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“Elijah, post:49, topic:327365”][quote author=eczema3 link=topic=423753.msg3113849#msg3113849 date=1264798071]

it won’t be long before a jailbreak is found, it’s most likely that a couple of tweaks to an existing jailbreak for OS 3.0 should work.

I doubt very strongly that there will be any Jailbreak for a long time. And if there is one soon, it’ll be patched quickly. Think of the iPhone as their dry run, they know all the tricks now. And I’m sure they made a point to stop people from Jailbreaking it. What I’m looking forward to, is linux on this thing.

It’s exactly the same fucking OS though… And it won’t be patched quickly, apple doesn’t work that fast.
[/quote]

I don’t think you understand what Jailbreaking does. It has nothing to do with the OS.[/quote]

Is that why you can use the same program to jailbreak the iPod touch 2nd gen with OS 3.0 and also iPod touch 3rd gen with OS 3.0?? Yeah, you’re right, it has nothing to do with the OS!

Read full topic

item.title: iPad
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

I wonder what the goal of this thing is. It’s not an e-reader, because you’d use an e-paper screen for that. It’s not a music player, because it’s too fucking big for that. Some call it a laptop in a big iWhatever case, but I expect at least a keyboard with feedback from a laptop. And of course, you can buy a real keyboard for the iPad, but looking at the pictures I doubt the keyboard can support the iPad without breaking eventually.

I’ll just compare the iPad with Sony’s Reader, because it’s something that I’d rather have then an iPad. I’ll take the most expensive one, the PRS-900BC, which is still $100,- cheaper then the cheapest iPad.

             PRS-900BC                   iPad

Price: $399 $499 for the 16GB edition, $599 for 32GB and $699 for 64GB
Dimensions: 5"x8.1"x0.6" 7.47"x9.56"x0.5"
(WxHxD)
Screen size: 7" 9.7"
Weight: 0.8 pounds 1.5/1.6 pounds
3G support: yes yes (if you pay $130 extra)
Memory: swappable 32GB SD 16/32/64GB fixed
Battery life: 12.000 pageturns 10 hours (let’s say it takes 4 minutes to read a page, you’ll be able to read 800 pages)
E-paper: YES! NO!

Especially the e-paper is a great feature which the iPad lacks. The iPad screen is too small for me to use it instead of a laptop. Heck, I’d rather use a netbook then an iPad because a netbook has a keyboard with feedback so you can actually type without spasming. What about watching a video? 7 inches, hello! Again, a laptop has a decent size screen, so I’d rather lose some space in my bag then having to stare at a (relative) tiny screen. So the only use you can think of for an iPad is reading books. But now we come back at the first sentence of this paragraph: The e-paper. An average book has about 350 pages. Many people dive into a book, and read one in two or three ‘sessions’. At a minute a page, which is quite fast, you’d be staring at an lcd screen for nearly two hours. While reading, you focus on small parts of the screen. This can’t be good for your eyes, so they’ll start bleeding by the time you’ve finished the first 5 chapters.

So e-paper is the way to go for e-readers.

I haven’t seen the complete presentation by Jobs yet, but in the excerpts I saw he talks about “a phenomenal browsing experience”. Anyone care to explain how it’s phenomenal?

Read full topic
